fullText: First Date is a pleasant enough diversion that makes the most of its modest ambitions. The show's best asset is its appealing leads, Zachary Levi and Krysta Rodriguez, who have an easy chemistry that makes you root for their characters.
dtliExcerpt: First Date is a pleasant enough diversion that makes the most of its modest ambitions. The show's best asset is its appealing leads, Zachary Levi and Krysta Rodriguez, who have an easy chemistry that makes you root for their characters.
bwwExcerpt: Levi is particularly winsome and adorable as Aaron..His singing voice, like his character, is engaging but a little thin...Here, [Rodriguez] projects an admirable magnetism as a brusque, red-meat-eating downtown chick...While director Bill Berry keeps the story zipping along, he's hobbled by a bland score (by Alan Zachary and Michael Weiner) that leans too heavily on pastiche as well as a paint-by-numbers book (by Austin Winsberg) that strings together a series of overly broad clich√©s rather than flesh out truly distinctive characters...But there's a certain crackle to the performances by Levi and Rodriguez, a kinetic in-the-momentness, that elevates the material. Though your head may tell you to cut short this First Date, you find yourself rooting for this unlikely couple (and the show) to succeed. C+
